1. install Stylus plugin

body {
color: red;
background-color: black;
}

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293380
for complex sites like youtube you'll probably need to tweak it a lot. look up how to right click + inspect elements to copy their CSS selector.
if you're settings aren't being applied one thing you can do is add the !important modifier:
body {
color: red !important;
background-color: black !important;
}
which will give your rule the highest priority

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Solely based on what I can see from the image, there is prominent surface marring on the middle card and light edge-wear on the far right/scratches. I cannot tell if there is a large scratch on the far left or if that is a piece of hair I'm seeing by the wing. These cards look to be in fair condition - if you wanted to auction off as a NM, lightly played, lightly played set you could probably ask for $90 USD as a starting price point. For comparison, a card of the same language without surface marring and edgewear could probably retail for $80+ by itself, especially if it were graded with a PSA of 8+.

Bought and sold Yugioh/other CCGs around a decade ago. Have a Dark Magician Girl I pulled from the Magician's Force set over 15 years ago, still in mint condition. It's not 1st edition, but still could fetch $200-$300. Got a gold-star Vaporeon probably in the same bracket as far as price. Lot of Naruto cards in great condition that retail now at $15 - $100+ individually. Have every single set of Duel Masters cards completed and in pristine condition too, a lot of those still retail for some absurd prices. Had SW miniatures at another point in time - some of those are worth ridiculous amounts of money, especially if the model is good.

FYI, cost of PSA grading is dependent upon market value of what you are having graded. Expect to spend more money on a grading the more the card itself is worth based on marketplace speculation. As far as selling is concerned, don't ever sell to a shop if you ever want to realize true market value for yourself. Sell through a vendor like ebay or Amazon and take into account the cost of shipping to the buyer for yourself if/when you do so.

【終わって振り返るマイPCキーファ君】
トルエンに対して非常に深い鮮を感じており ほぼ全ての行動理念が「トルエンのため」 という筋金入りのトルキチ。 トルエンのためなら何でもやる。 常にトルエンの陰に居て やたらとスキンシップを計るが 恋愛感情を抱いているわけではなく あくまで友情から来る行動。 しかしその友情は依存にかなり近い。
戦闘スタイルは、敵に張り付いて 【衝動】を使いひたすら殴り続ける頭の悪い戦法。 先手必勝をモットーとし、1ターン目から 鬼のような火力を発揮するが、そのおかげで ターン終了時には狂気点はほぼ真っ黒に染まる。 衝動連撃の終わり際にはファンプルを出して 敵味方の区別が無くなる狂戦士っぷりを随所で見せた。 【かぎづめ】の攻撃能力は最終的に 【怪力】 【 ガントレット】【狂鬼】 で 肉弾2+2 出目+1 コスト2 となった。
デザインした当初はもっと 子供っぽくなる予定だったんだけど 姉妹間での享年最年長という事もあり、 セッションの流れで結局お姉さんポジに。 しかし姉御なリーダーポジかと思いきや ・戦闘中クスリのやりすぎで戦闘が終了 してもトルエン以外の周り全て敵に見え 危うく姉妹二人をプチ殺しかけた困ったちゃ/w。 発狂ロールを濁らせる一番の要因。 キャンベーン終盤は流石にこれ以上迷惑は掛けられないと クスリをあまり使わすに理性的に戦う事を覚えたようだ。 (実情は対話判定に失敗し続け狂気点に余裕が無くなり 衝動があまり使えなくなったから)|
ここでは語らないけど、生前の話でも超好みなキャラに してもらったのでNCにとても感謝してる。

sub: Help a black anon install Ubuntu
com:
So I wanted to install Ubuntu on my old PC as I want to switch to GNU/Linux. My first stop was Ubuntu, I used Rufus to make a bootable USB drive with the MBR partition scheme (GPT goes unnoticed) and it sends me to grub rescue. I dont have dual boot on the PC just Win10. After I get to the grub rescue I typed the commands that I've seen on YT https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OJTGpvZO8Oc&ab_channel=EasyTechs:

set boot=(hd0,msdos5)
set ...
After doing insmod normal it says no such partition found.
I had Ubuntu on this PC a couple of years ago the install went fine and I want to again emphasize that this is an old PC, maybe bought in 2007.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: post forearm

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
idk how that grub stuff works
try a few other distros and see if it's the same deal with all of them

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293190
The ubuntu image you're downloading might be meant for GPT, so you're putting a GPT bootloader on an MBR partition.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293264
>The ubuntu image you're downloading might be meant for GPT
>>1293190
>GPT goes unnoticed
You guys are so confused.

GPT and MBR are partition table formats.
(U)EFI and Legacy are booting methods.
Legacy requires MBR, because only the MBR partition table has a block for the Legacy bootloader code to go in.

USB sticks shouldn't be partitioned at all, they use "Superfloppy", which is simply a bare partition taking up the entire disk.

>>1293190
>I dont have dual boot on the PC just Win10
If it came with 10, you almost certainly have UEFI. Check this by looking in Disk Management: if you have a GPT disk, definitely UEFI. If you have a EFI System Partition, almost certainly UEFI.

If you're on UEFI, you need to find an Ubuntu image that can boot using UEFI, and follow instructions for installing Ubuntu on UEFI. Linux documentation on this matter is SHIT. EFI became the default in 2012, but looking at the Linux world you'd think it came out this year. Most tutorials for installing Ubuntu are hilariously out of date.

On EFI, you shouldn't need to use any weird program to make a USB bootable, just format it FAT32, open the ISO in Explorer and drag the files across, and EFI should be able to boot it.

Maybe try making a Windows 10 USB with the Media Creation Tool first, and see if you can boot that. This eliminates all the variables and the weird third-party tools. Once you can boot a Windows 10 USB, you can make a Linux USB.

Ubuntu is supposed to be Secure Boot signed, but try turning off Secure Boot if it won't boot it.

Thanks a lot. I get the parts I missed on the way to the last step, but why does multiplying the right side by 2/2 push the Q outside the fraction?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I get that 2Q/2 is just Q/1, but intuitively multiplying the fraction by 2/2 makes it 2Q(b+1/2)/2(1+1/2b) for me.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293217
Thank you kind internet cat

>>1293222
Not that anon, but: Q already got moved outside the fraction a step earlier, going from
>(1+0.5b)P = (b+0.5)Q
to
>P = [(b+0.5)/(1+0.5b)]Q

Anon did two things in one step here, which is commonly done because the second step is so simple:

(1+0.5b)P = (b+0.5)Q

dividing by (1+0.5b) to isolate P
P = [(b+0.5)Q] / (1+0.5b)

divide Q out of the fraction
P = [(b+0.5) / (1+0.5b)] Q

This last step is allowed because (A*B)/C = (A/C)*B.

name: Anonymous
com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit
>>1263648

com:
How do you back up your data /wsr/?
Can you guys recommend me software that handles that for me?

I have around 1.5 TB of data that I want to keep a backup of.
I copied it manually to 2 HDDs for the last couple of years but it became bothersome to manage that shit.
Dunno some software that syncs data on both HDDs would be nice?
Also had one HDD die on me without even noticing so I'm afraid one day my shit will be lost.

Should I set up a RAID?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292817
I've been using FreeFileSync. It's free, opensource, and by far the best backup software by features as well: https://freefilesync.org/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292817

>Should I set up a RAID?

Depends on what you want to protect against.

A RAID is used when you are afraid of losing your stuff through drive crashes and hardware failures.
It uses redundancy to prevent data loss by a disk failure.
It does NOT protect against active destruction via software. Put in sudo rm -rf and the removing is mirrored over all drives so your data is lost on every one. Get a destructive virus or ransomware and it has its fun over all your disks.

Personally I simply every few months mirror over my entire system to an external disk via dd which then goes into storage again.
An external disk wothout power cannot software corrupt and should be relatively safe against the most common failure types which come from the moving parts (there is of course never 100% safety, it could lost its calibration in the firmware for example or some other defect while not running, but seriously, at some point you just have to accept that there will always be a ramining risk. if you want to minimize it do it twice on different disks from different manufacturers which you store differently).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293063
>A RAID is used when you are afraid of losing your stuff through drive crashes and hardware failures.
No, it provides availability of the storage device through hardware failures, it does not prevent loss of your stuff at all.
- RAM goes bad
- OS uses that chunk of RAM as the disk cache
- nonsense sectors get reliably strewn identically throughout multiple disks
>I simply every few months mirror over my entire system to an external disk via dd which then goes into storage again.
Not a terrible idea, but consider filling the empty space on the live filesystem with zeroes, then checking it into a bup repository on the external disk. Depending on your sizes and churn rate, you should be able to get a bunch of snapshots into the same space.

Also, just to check, you are doing this on a readonly filesystem or one that's unmounted, right? You can't do this on most filesystems when they're mounted RW, because dd accesses the storage device directly, but the VFS filesystem driver accesses it through the disk cache, so the filesystem driver is seeing the dirty pages correctly and dd is seeing whatever garbage used to be there. In addition, any writes whilst dd is running will be captured if they're written in front of the position dd has gotten to, but won't be if they're written to the space it's already covered. This can include writes to the same file if its allocation is fragmented.

Hopefully you already know all this, but it would suck to think you were meticulously making backups only to find out they're all busted.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293070
>>1293063
Note that on Windows you *can* do disk2vhd/system-image-backup on a running system, because windows offers "volume shadow copy", an API that lets these tools access an unchanging snapshot of the disk whilst they're backing it up. When you write to a disk that's undergoing a VSC transaction, VSC hides your writes from the program that's using VSC, storing all the information it needs to undo all your changes and present the disk to the backup program as if they never happened. It also lets applications like Exchange, SQL Server, Outlook and so on register with VSC and put their on-disk files in a consistent state to be included in the backup.

Linux can't do this, though ZFS (which isn't in Linux because license conflict) can, as can APFS on OSX.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292817
>I have around 1.5 TB of data that I want to keep a backup of.
- get a 2TB SSD for everyday use
- get a 2-3TB external disk for backup
- get a 8GB USB stick
- use system image backup, included in Windows since Windows 7, to back up to the external disk
- this should automatically snapshot, so the second backup will only be the stuff that changed since the first backup. But don't quote me on that.
- make a Windows installer USB with the media creation tool, so you already have one before you need it

If your backup device dies:
- immediately buy a new one and make a new backup as normal
If your SSD dies:
- buy a new one, and install it
- boot off the windows USB with the backup disk connected
- instead of pressing "install windows" press "repair this PC" then "restore from backup"
If you need a random file from a backup
- log on as administrator
- go to disk management and select "mount VHD"
- mount the VHD inside "windows backups" readonly, then open the drive letter in Explorer and copy out whatever you need

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1293021
>So here is my motherboard, it only supports 1st and 2nd gen cpus. However, I want to change my CPU for an amd R5 4500...
Where is your motherboard?
Anyways, go to your motherboard manufacturer's website, find that motherboard, go to the support page, and look at the CPU compatibility list. If the CPU's there, then it will work. If the CPU's there but it says "latest Beta BIOS", then it will work after you update the BIOS.

Be aware, on motherboards with low-capacity BIOS chips, installing the latest BIOS with support for 4th/5th generation processors will actually REMOVE support for first-generation processors. So read the notes, find out if that's the case, and if it is then what you'll want to do is
- wait until everything's arrived and you're ready to go
- restart windows and go into the BIOS
- update the BIOS using the option in the BIOS
- shut down
- upgrade the CPU
- boot into the BIOS, save settings, and restart

To change the processor back, you need to do the same thing but with your old BIOS. You don't have to worry about any of this if the new BIOS doesn't remove support for your CPU.

com:
is there a way to find the html file paths of a particular domain ?
say there's a website called random.net, but it's a blank page with no link to direct you to its subpages;
how do you find all its sub pages like random.net/sub-page ?
sorry if this sounds autistic

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: You can't. Search engines work by crawling all of the links starting from the root (/) or references on other websites (e.g. another website linking to random.net/sub-page).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292728
If it's on the internet archive, you can look there
e.g. http://web.archive.org/web/*/random.net*
Obviously this only works for pages that are linked to somewhere on the internet and got hit by archive.org's web crawler

com: I have this component, and don't have a soldering iron. I do have, however, a shit ton of electrical tape. How do I attach the thing on the bottom to the thing on the top so I can run jumpers off of it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292877
Not really. Maybe with copper tape.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292877
You cannot. Go get a soldering iron.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292877
Warning: super emergency solution, if you are okay with possibly ruining the board. Also pretty intricate.
You can try to jam the pins by sticking something thin that fits in every hole on -one- side between the board and the pins. A toothpick end if the gap is big enough or some paper (foil is pretty good if you are careful not to make new connections, disregard one side rule in this case). If you managed to balance everything out so that every pin touches metal of its hole reliably, superglue every hole (don't apply too much so it doesn't go on other components). Then you have to be very careful inserting it in as superglue is brittle, maybe help it go in by gently applying pressure to all the pins from the top. Then you never disconnect it if you want it working, assume first disconnect will break it.
If you are not in immediate need of a bodge job just buy a cheapo chinese soldering iron, they are very good for the price.
